title-group.title: The interplay between Reynolds stress and zonal flows: direct numerical simulation as a bridge between theory and experiment

address-group.address: Laboratoire de physique des plasmas—Laboratorium voor Plasmafysica, Association ‘Euratom-Etat Belge’—Associatie ‘Euratom-Belgische Staat’, Ecole Royale Militaire—Koninklijke Militaire School, Avenue de la Renaissance 30—Renaissancelaan 30, B-1000 Brussels, Belgium (Partner in Trilateral Euregio Cluster).

abstract.heading: Abstract
abstract.p: We describe the results of a measurement campaign on the CASTOR tokamak where the drive of flows and zonal flows by Reynolds stress was investigated by means of a dual probe head system allowing us to measure the properties of the electrostatic turbulence and the rotation velocities at the same location and at the same moment. We compare these experimental results with a turbulence model linked to a one dimensional fluid model describing the electrostatic turbulence and its influence on the background flow. The turbulence is simulated locally on the basis of the Hasegawa–Wakatani equations, completed with magnetic inhomogeneity terms. In the fluid model the toroidal geometry is correctly taken into account, while various sources and sinks like viscosity, interaction with neutrals, Reynolds stress and electric current induced by biasing are included. The good agreement of the predicted flow with the measured one demonstrates that in a pure cylindrical geometry the modelled strength of Reynolds stress acceleration of flow is overestimated.

sec-level1.heading: Introduction
sec-level1.p: In magnetized plasmas it is often found that the cross-field transport exceeds by far the expected (neo) classical diffusive transport due to collisions. This ‘anomalous’ transport dramatically reduces the confinement and is due to turbulence, driven by various sources such as density or temperature gradients and curvature [1]. For the successful exploitation of a fusion reactor, the understanding of the nature of the turbulence as well as the study of strategies to control and/or reduce it are therefore of major importance.

Sheared flows which rip the convective cells apart have long been invoked as a major control mechanism to quench the turbulence. Such flows can be established by various means such as electrode biasing [2] and neutral beam injection [3] and show the direct impact of background poloidal and toroidal rotation on the turbulence [4]. The turbulence however also influences the background flows via the so-called Reynolds stress as was first put forward by Diamond in search of a mechanism to explain L- to H-mode transition. This inverse phenomenon has been studied both on the theoretical [5] and on the experimental side [6].

Nonlinear interaction, the agent behind Reynolds stress, is also at the basis of the self-organization of the turbulence. Zonal flows, defined as large scale poloidally-extended coherent structures (k___ENT___ < kr, but k___ENT___ nonzero), can, for example, quench smaller scale turbulence, a phenomenon that, because of the self-similar nature of the turbulence, can be expected to be active on different spatial scales.

As the pioneering work in this domain by Xu [6] was impeded by a lack of precise quantitative measurements of the poloidal rotation in HT-6M, we now aim at further documenting the interaction between the background flow and turbulence via Reynolds stress by comparing the results of a dedicated experimental campaign on the CASTOR tokamak to the predictions of theoretical models describing the turbulence and the behaviour of the background flow. In addition we investigate the role of Reynolds stress in the self-organization and behaviour of the turbulence.

By means of a manipulator, inserted at the top of the machine, and holding a Gundestrup probe to measure the rotation velocities, as well as a dedicated Reynolds stress probe (RS-probe, see figure 1) [7] we were able to measure the background flow and the turbulence properties simultaneously and at the same location. Different shots then allowed us to establish radial profiles. We investigated Ohmic plasmas as well as scenarios where rotation is driven by electrode biasing.
Schematic drawing of the experimental set-up at CASTOR.

On the other hand, we built an electrostatic turbulence code based on the Hasegawa–Wakatani equations (HWE) [8] in two-dimensional (2D) (x, y), extended with magnetic inhomogeneity (these terms are commonly called curvature terms), so that the rectangular grid (x, y) could be mapped on a 2D (r, ___ENT___) domain. First of all, we confront this model with the experimentally measured turbulence and make an extensive comparison between the code simulations and the experiment.

Then we study the influence of the turbulence on the background flow by means of a one-dimensional (1D) fluid model which describes the poloidal acceleration of the plasma due to a gradient in Reynolds stress and electrode biasing. Various damping mechanisms such as bulk viscosity and drag due to neutral particles are also included. Furthermore, compared with previous work [5], the curvature is correctly taken into account, giving rise to the neoclassical factor 1 + 2q2 in certain terms [7]. For this model we need the surface averaged gradient of the Reynolds stress, a quantity that can be computed only if the poloidal dependence of the turbulence is known. As we have no experimental clue, we use the extended HWE model to establish the poloidal dependence by direct numerical simulation. We thus obtain a model function that can be used to compute the flux surface average. The model is then used to study the experimentally obtained rotation.
Finally we comment on the role the Reynolds stress plays in the creation of zonal flows and show experimental evidence.

The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. We start in section 2 by presenting our simulations based on the set of the extended HWE, which has been validated by the measured data taken at CASTOR and furthermore lead to a model function describing the poloidal dependence of the strength of the Reynolds stress. In section 3, the 1D fluid model, which includes this Reynolds stress term, is explained and is compared as well with the experimental observations at HT-6M and CASTOR. In section 4 conclusions are drawn.

sec-level1.heading: Turbulence modelling
sec-level1.p:
The simplest model that allows us to describe this experiment is the Hasegawa–Wakatani model [8], to which we added curvature terms [9] in view of a study of the poloidal dependence of the turbulence:
The primes denote dimensionless quantities (radial dimension, x′ = x/ρs, perpendicular distance, y′ = y/ρs, parallel coordinate, z′, time, t′ = ωcit, density n′ = ≁/n0 and potential ___ENT___′ = e___ENT___sim/T) with ρs the ion Larmor radius at electron temperature and ωci the ion cyclotron frequency. The Poisson brackets constitute the nonlinear part of the HWE. We also added a particle diffusion in the electron continuity equation to increase the stability during the numerical calculations [10].

The magnetic field inhomogeneity depends on the poloidal angle through the curvature operator , with ωB = (2ρs/R0) and R0 the major radius. There is no effect of magnetic field shear included in the model, or equivalently the safety factor q is constant over the computational domain. The adiabaticity coefficient of the electron response is abbreviated (with σz the electron conductivity in the parallel direction) and the kinematic ion shear viscosity, μ = η1/n0/Mi [11], is introduced by .

The normalized driving background density gradient is introduced via κ = − ∂ (ln n0)/∂x′, and determines through the assumption of maximum growth rate. Therefore we write the dispersion relation of the set HWE by neglecting the viscosity (C2 = 0) and the curvature terms (ωB = 0):
in which ω1 = ky κ/(1 + k2) and b = C1(1 + k2)/k2. We rather find C1 ≈ k2 ky (∂(lnn0)/∂x′)/(1 + k2)2 instead of the quadruple of this value as reported in the original paper. We derived the exact solution (b ≈ ω1, as is obtained as well in [12]) and did not approximate the final condition, , as is done in [8]. These values for the parallel wavenumber (or equivalently C1) result in increased levels of fluctuations, leading to more realistic values when compared with the experiment.

The evolution of the dynamical equations (1) and (2) is computed locally by a pseudospectral code on a rectangular grid of 33 × 33 with periodic boundary conditions. As the computational domain is sufficiently restricted in radial as well as in poloidal extent, all coefficients can be considered constant on the domain. The real space between two different grid points is smaller than half a gyro radius: in all calculations we used as grid spacing, ρs/2.1 (for typical values, see the next section), so that the maximum dimensionless wavenumber is 2.1 π in both directions. Wavenumbers in a modulus larger than 2 π are artificially damped by a hyperviscosity [13]. The time-stepping algorithm is based on a predictor–corrector scheme.

sec-level2.heading: Confrontation with experimental data
sec-level2.p: To compare with the data taken at CASTOR and reported in [7], we put 3 ‘probe pins’ in the grid (33 × 33 points = 8 × 8 mm in real units) at the same relative position as the pins of the real probe used in [7] (at the top of the poloidal section, see figure 1). We simulated the self consistent evolution of turbulence on the basis of equations (1) and (2) and sampled the signals at the same frequency as during the experiment (1 MHz). The coefficients are computed according to the edge parameters of CASTOR (Ti ≈ 20 eV, ni = 1 × 1019 m−3, ∇ni = −5 × 1020 m−4 and R0 = 0.40 m, a = 0.085 m, BT = 1.3 T), leading to ρs ≈ 0.4 mm, ωci = 1.2 × 108 rad s−1, κ = −0.02, C1 ∈ −0.005, …, 0.005, C2 = 1.2 × 10−4 and ωB = 2 × 10−3. These values are at the low end of the spectrum of the cases treated in the original paper [8].

We can now compare the simulated and the experimental signals. First, we study the correlation properties of the fluctuations. The data analysis of the signals coming from the real experiment and from the virtual probe pins on the grid are both made in the laboratory frame. In our simulation model, there is no background electric field and thus no corresponding drift. To correctly identify the correlation properties of the turbulence and also make the comparison significant, we choose the radial position of the probe to be the one where the radial electric field measured on CASTOR is minimum so that the flow-effect on the turbulence correlation is negligible.

The correlation time obtained for both signals is of the order of Tcorr ≈ 5–6 µs, as can be seen in figure 2, which depicts the e-folding time of the normalized autocorrelation function of the sampled potential fluctuations ( , with the time lag Δt a multiple of the sample period), obtained by simulation (dotted line) and by measurement (full line). This function can be computed in each point of the simulation grid and for all the measurement points of the probe. Here we have represented only one typical curve. Similar values have been found for other locations and other probe-pins. A correlation time of the same order was reported by Hron in [14].
Auto-correlation function for the potential fluctuations by simulation and on CASTOR (r/a = 0.88). Note that these curves refer to a simulation and to experimental data with respect to the laboratory frame.

Next we compare the fluctuation levels of ___ENT___sim and the Reynolds stress ( , which is actually a zero-delay cross-correlation function between two fluctuating quantities, and , shown in figure 3). It is clear that the simulated fluctuation levels are somewhat lower than experimentally observed (a factor of three for the raw data, a factor of five for the Reynolds stress). This discrepancy can be partially explained by the assumption of homogeneous temperature in the model as discussed in [15].
Top: floating potential fluctuations (dimensionless) at r/a = 0.97 in CASTOR (a) and simulated (b). Bottom: time-averaged value (––––: rapid fluctuations with a boxcar window of 10 µs; ······: slow fluctuations with one of 100 µs) of Reynolds stress at r/a = 0.97 in CASTOR (c) and from simulation (d).

Plotting the time trace of the spectrally defined, instantaneous radial diffusion coefficient for a simulation at ___ENT___ = 0 (outboard, see figure 4, chosen for reasons of clarity), we remark a phenomenon of intermittency [16]. The horizontal line on the bottom plot of figure 4 represents the rms-value of the complete time sequence (Drms = 1.61). Moments during which D is temporarily higher than this value can be identified as strong bursts with high particle loss (‘high activity’), in opposition to the ‘quiet’ periods.
Simulation at outboard (___ENT___ = 0). Top: instantaneous values of Reynolds stress (RS) (m2 s−2). Bottom: instantaneous turbulence driven diffusion coefficient (D) (m2 s−1).

The rms-value at ___ENT___ = 0 is more than twice the value of the same quantity for a simulation at ___ENT___ = π/2 (see figure 7) and agrees well with the real experimentally observed anomalous particle diffusion (for CASTOR is the experimental value of D of the order of unity, expressed in metres square per second).

During the ‘quiet’ periods we also see that the radial diffusion is strongly reduced (by a factor of 3 to the mean value, Dmean ≈ 0.9 m2 s−1). Interestingly, the periods of strong diffusion seem to be accompanied by more Reynolds stress activity (instantaneous values, derived from a spectral ensemble average, represented as ), and vice versa. This means that the Reynolds stress and the turbulence driven diffusion coefficient are closely related. We are investigating this relationship more profoundly to clarify the link.

The intermittent behaviour of the turbulence can be further analysed by way of the standard k-spectrum (figure 5). The figure depicts the kx = kr and ky = k___ENT___ spectra at a certain moment (instantaneous) during the simulation, which falls in a situation of ‘high activity’ (figure 5(a)) or within a ‘quiet’ (figure 5(b)) window. We always see that a structure with k___ENT___ < kr is present during the quiet periods. This structure is not present during the periods of high ‘activity’.
Instantaneous wavenumber-spectra for the potential fluctuations during (a) a turbulent situation (‘high activity’); (b) a possible ‘zonal flow’ (‘quiet’) situation.

A possible interpretation is that a zonal flow develops and that it temporarily quenches the turbulent ‘activity’. With the restrictions on the grid size, the condition for a zonal flow is rather difficult to verify on the wavenumber-spectrum (see peaks A and B on figure 5(b)).

A simple snapshot of the grid (not shown in this paper, see [17]) at a moment where the turbulence is saturated reveals that the density and the potential fluctuations are out of phase. Furthermore, the density fluctuations always incorporate more small scale (turbulent) structures than the potential fluctuations. A typical cross-correlation coefficient between n′ and ___ENT___′ is ≈0.15, compared with ≈0.2–0.35 experimentally (depending on minor radius).

A further cross-check of the code can be done by looking at the wavenumber–frequency spectrum shown in figure 6, derived from ohmical CASTOR data by the experimental two-point correlation technique, as proposed in [18].
Wavenumber-frequency spectrum S(k___ENT___, f) from CASTOR ((a) at r/a = 0.97, (b) at r/a = 0.88) and (c) from simulation. The ion diamagnetic direction is represented here in the positive direction.

The experiment (figures 6(a) and (b)) reveals a phase velocity, , of the order of 5 km s−1 (at r/a = 0.97) and −2 km s−1 (at r/a = 0.88) in the ion and electron diamagnetic direction, respectively, while the simulation gives vph = −2 km s−1 (figure 6(c)). In the simulation, vph is only driven by the pressure gradient ( ) as there is no background radial electric field ( ) set in the code. Experimentally, is related to both the drift and the velocity. Therefore, we compare the simulation result with figure 6(b), made at r/a = 0.88 on CASTOR, where is minimal. The -velocity in the edge in CASTOR is of the order of 1 km s−1, while the simulated is twice as large as this velocity and both in the electron diamagnetic direction as expected from the drift wave turbulence. At the location of r/a = 0.97, the calculated flow is around 4 km s−1 (in the ion diamagnetic direction) and dominates clearly the phase velocity of the fluctuations in CASTOR at that position. This situation confirms studies in other tokamaks, as reported in [19].

sec-level2.heading: Poloidal dependence of the Reynolds stress and the diffusion coefficient
sec-level2.p:
We are now ready to analyse the dependence of the different quantities on the poloidal angle (___ENT___ = 0 at the low field side). Two effects have to be taken into account. Firstly the parameter C2 depends on B, so that it varies with ___ENT___. The same is true for the reference value used in the definition of the dimensionless parameters. Secondly the curvature operator depends explicitly on ___ENT___. In figure 7 we show the computed rms-value of the Reynolds stress and the (in time) averaged diffusion coefficient. The time-window, over which the average is taken, is situated in the saturated regime and spans over several milliseconds. As can be seen, the curvature amplifies the effect that the normalization has on the fluctuations (comparison is represented for Reynolds stress only).
Reynolds stress (○: with curvature; ▿: without curvature) and diffusion coefficient (⋄) as a function of the poloidal angle of the centre of the domain. A curve of the form RSHFS(1 + b cos2(___ENT___/2)) is fitted to the data.

Beside the exceptional outcome of the simulation at ___ENT___ = 0, one can fit the dependence of the Reynolds stress on ___ENT___ by a function of the form, RS(___ENT___) = RSHFS(1 + b cos2(___ENT___/2)). The measurements being taken at the top of the tokamak (___ENT___ = π/2), we would then postulate the link, RSEXP = RSHFS(1+ (b/2)), between the model and experiment. RSHFS = RS___ENT___=π is the multiplying constant, approximately one tenth of the maximal value of the Reynolds stress close to the outboard plane, and b = 9 consequently. Checking numerically the flux-surface-average of the represented simulated points in figure 7 against the flux-surface-average obtained with the proposed function, we see a difference of the order of 15%. We will thus use this model function when the flux surface averaged Reynolds stress is needed. Concerning the diffusion coefficient, we see—as expected—that the turbulent activity is stronger at the low field side of a tokamak.

sec-level1.heading: The interaction between turbulence and background flow
sec-level1.p: We now come to the possible influence the turbulence has on the background flow. As demonstrated by Xu in [6], in certain circumstances, the Reynolds stress can drive background flow. In this section we wish to further analyse this possibility and corroborate it by the CASTOR experiments.

We start from the Braginskii equations [11] and follow the method originally proposed by Reynolds and used by Peeters [20], writing the fluid velocity and the density n as a mean plus a fluctuating part ( , n = n + ≁). The mean is defined as a time-average, x = ⟨x⟩τ, with the timescale of averaging τ large compared with the timescale of the fluctuations but short with respect to any macroscopical timescale. is called the total velocity and transforms the total momentum equation in the form (higher order terms in fluctuations are neglected)
in which is the Reynolds stress term and is the neutral friction force with n ν* = n (nneutrals ⟨σ · v⟩), the neutral friction coefficient [21]. The other symbols have their usual meaning.

With the same definition, it is possible to write the continuity equation in the form, . Expressing this equation in toroidal coordinates ((r, ___ENT___, υ), denoting the radial, poloidal and toroidal coordinates, respectively), and restricting the model to a circular poloidal cross-section as in CASTOR, one can define the flux-surface-averaged poloidal rotation, ⟨U___ENT___⟩flux = (F(r)/R0), and write the poloidal velocity as U___ENT___ = (R0/R)(F(r)/R0), where use is made of the flux surface average operation, defined as , and where R = R0 + r cos ___ENT___.

The turbulence is supposed to be electrostatic [8], so that lies in the perpendicular plane. An important consequence of this statement is that , so that (Θ = tan α, with α the pitch of the magnetic field). This results finally in a rather simple form for the Reynolds stress terms in the toroidal and parallel components of equation (3). It is easy to show that one can write the complete Reynolds stress tensor in function of the covariance between the two fluctuating velocities ( , commonly called the Reynolds stress) and of the two variances and .

Taking the divergence of this tensor, and projecting equation (3) on the toroidal and parallel direction, we can write an equation for F(r), or—equivalently—the flux-surface-averaged poloidal velocity [22–24]. As we only wish to model a narrow radial layer we take the safety factor q to be constant. With a poloidal dependence for the Reynolds stress established in the previous section, we find
In this equation, the convection has been neglected and the viscosity is reduced to C · ((F(r)/R0) − UNeo), where for the collisional regime and UNeo = (−2.1/Z e B0)(∂Ti/∂r) [22].

When comparing this equation with the form proposed by Diamond in [5] ( ) and also used in [6], the most conspicuous difference, apart from the presence of additional source and sink terms, is the presence of the neo-classical factor (1 + 2q2). This factor importantly reduces the influence of the Reynolds stress with respect to the prediction of [5] as it is of the order of 10–100 in the edge of a tokamak. The poloidal dependence of the Reynolds stress does not compensate this factor. It is also clear that a poloidal dependence of the form f(___ENT___) = RSHFS(1 + b cos2(___ENT___/2)) does not lead to a different result compared with a homogeneous distribution of the Reynolds stress as previously used in [7]. It is noteworthy to mention the importance of the place where the fluctuation measurements are taken. A measurement at the top of the tokamak is a good approximation for the flux-surface-average of the Reynolds stress.

sec-level2.heading: Confronting the model with data taken at CASTOR and HT-6M
sec-level2.p: To investigate the possible role of Reynolds stress in driving rotation, a quite promising campaign was held at HT-6M by Xu et al and reported in [6]. Turbulence was imposed by a turbulent heating (TH) pulse, creating temporarily very steep gradients in the Reynolds stress strength. The drawbacks of this campaign, however, were the uncertainty about the absolute magnitude of the poloidal velocity and the possibility that the TH pulse induces not only electrostatic turbulence in the edge. Indeed, imposing a TH pulse could result also in a non-negligible electromagnetic component of the turbulence (Maxwell stresses). The eventual conclusion, based on an analysis using the model of [5] was however that the Reynolds stress was responsible for the observed rotation.

To further corroborate these conclusions and to validate our model (equation (4)), where the additional effect of the neoclassical factor is present, we will now further analyse the obtained CASTOR data. Ohmic shots in an hydrogen-plasma were performed with machine parameters as mentioned above, but with high q-values (q = 15) to stress in particular the effect of q in the equation (4). We limit our analysis to Ohmic shots, since our turbulence code assumes a fixed background density profile, prohibiting any transition-inducing scenario. Moreover, during the biasing phase itself, the Reynolds stress influence is completely overwhelmed by the biasing-induced radial current torque (see also [7]).

Figure 8 shows a typical radial profile of the Reynolds stress and its gradient for such an Ohmic scenario. The full line is the radial derivative of the different markers, being the average of all individual measurements of the Reynolds stress at that radius. The error-bars on the plots are obtained by comparing several reproducible shots. The Reynolds stress is of the same order of the one measured in HT-6M [6], but the gradient is less pronounced and the error-bars are more important. The gradient develops a few millimetres inside the separatrix; the error-bars in this region are also the largest.
Top: a snapshot of Reynolds stress measurements by the two different triplets (123) and (345), at t = 12.9 ms. Bottom: radial gradient of Reynolds stress in Ohmic discharges

To check the prediction of our 1D fluid model, we apply the measured Reynolds stresses in equation (4) and obtain the results shown in figure 9, using the real values of q, η0 and Ti and supposing a neutral density of 1016 m−3 everywhere. Note that figure 8 only shows a snapshot of the Reynolds stress, while figure 9 uses the different actual successive values of the Reynolds stresses between 12 and 13 ms to compute the poloidal velocity profile as a function of time. Because the plasma is during these Ohmic shots in a rather stationary state, no appreciable difference exists between these snapshots of the Reynolds stress.
Poloidal velocities, simulated by equation (4), starting from the measured profile at t = 12 ms with the real q-values and with the mean gradient derived from shot to shot.

We see a clear damping of the flow close to the separatrix and an acceleration of the flow further inside. This acceleration can only be due to the Reynolds stress. Moreover, to obtain this result we took the real value of q (in CASTOR the shots were done at a large q(a) ≃ 15) and used the successive profiles from figure 8 at the subsequent times. If q is taken equal to zero (reducing our model to a cylindrical approximation), we obtain accelerations that are two orders of magnitude too high and which cannot be damped by increasing the neutral density as then the damping close to the separatrix would be far too high, so that the flows would be reduced to zero over the simulated length of time. This is not experimentally observed, so we tend to conclude that the factor of 1+2q2 seems to be justified in this case.

A rather severe consequence of this reasoning is that we do not believe that gradients in electrostatic Reynolds stress, in the amount that they are present (and measurable with Langmuir probes) on different tokamaks [25], can be solely responsible for a macroscopic poloidal k___ENT___ = 0 acceleration. Our model confirms that a radial gradient in the Reynolds stress is indeed a driving term, capable of sustaining a certain poloidal velocity in the steady state, but—on the other hand—its raw strength is divided by the factor 1 + 2q2 with respect to driving the flux-surface-averaged poloidal velocity. However, this conclusion on the k___ENT___ = 0 component does not impede the Reynolds stress's local drive of a zonal flow.

sec-level1.heading: Conclusion
sec-level1.p: Our turbulence model leads to relevant results with respect to the measurements made at the edge in CASTOR. Although the level of the fluctuations is slightly too low (one order of magnitude for the Reynolds stress), the correlation time and the turbulence driven diffusion coefficient can be simulated in accordance with the experimentally observed values. Besides this, the simulations show an intermittent behaviour of the turbulence, as is found as well on CASTOR. The model predicts the (temporary) existence of zonal flows in the saturated state of the turbulence, during which the anomalous diffusion is reduced.

The extension of this comparison with the experiment towards the full poloidal cross section leads to a model function that we used in the 1D fluid description to compute the flux-surface-averaged influence of the Reynolds stress.

From our 1D fluid description, we conclude that the driving force, coming from the electrostatic Reynolds stresses, is divided by 1 + 2q2 for what concerns the k___ENT___ = 0 component of the poloidal velocity. The comparison between the model and the experiment (Ohmic regime) confirms the driving capabilities of a gradient in the Reynolds stress profile. Nevertheless, the factor makes it hard to believe that gradients in the electrostatic Reynolds stress, in the amount that they are measured in the edge of present tokamaks, can be solely responsible for the major poloidal acceleration in the edge, invoking a steady shear layer and consequently a L- to H-mode transition.
